ELECTION OF SPEAKER


    

    The Leader of the House (Mr E. W. Barker) stood up, and addressing himself to the Clerk of Parliament said: Mr Lopez, I propose,

    That Dr Yeoh Ghim Seng do take the Chair of this Parliament as Speaker.

Column: 4



    

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu) stood up, and addressing himself to the Clerk of Parliament said. Mr Lopez, I support the proposal.

    There being no other proposal, the Clerk then declared Dr Yeoh Ghim Seng to have been elected as Speaker of Parliament.

2.32 p.m.

    The Leader of the House (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I, on behalf of all the Members of this House, extend to you our congratulations on the occasion of your re-election as Speaker.

    It was my pleasure, Sir, in January, 1970, on your election to this high office for the first time, to extend to you the congratulations of the House. I stated then that you were the fourth person to hold this high office since the introduction of parliamentary government, and that you had broken what could have crystallised into a convention that the office of the Speaker should fall on the shoulders of those with a legal training. Over these last two years and ten months, you have ably demonstrated that legal qualifications are not a sine qua non for wearing the mantle of this office. The aplomb, dignity and mariner in which you have so ably discharged your responsibilities amply confirms you as the one most fitted to guide our proceedings.

    Sir, you will be presiding over deliberations of an enlarged Chamber of 65 Members, of whom no less than 11 will be taking their seats in this House for the first time. I have no doubt that you will give these new Members the same considerate guidance that you have shown to all of us in the past. You may be assured, Sir, that for our part, we will continue to give you all the co-operation necessary for the speedy despatch of parliamentary business.

    Mr Speaker: I would first like to thank the Leader of the House for his kind words on my re-election as Speaker.

    Mr Prime Minister, honourable Ministers, honourable Members, you have greatly honoured me by re-electing

Column: 6

me as Speaker of this House and I feel very privileged to continue to serve the House in this high and responsible office.

    My first election to this Chair on the 27th of January, 1970, was a proud moment in my life though I must say it was not without some trepidation as I appreciated then, as I do now, the responsibilities of this office. However, the unstinted co-operation of honourable Members of the House greatly lightened my task in the Speaker's Chair. The majority of you here now were then with me in Parliament and I would like to express my gratitude to you for your kindness and indulgence at any of my shortcomings and also for your loyalty to me. If I had seemed on occasions to have been stern, believe me, I was striving to adhere strictly to the rules of the House.

    I wish to welcome the new honourable Members who have joined us. I have no doubt that the older Members will be happy to advise you on procedure not only in this House but also in the Committees of the House. Do remember that Mr Speaker is your friend though he may at times not appear to be so. I may add that my staff will also be ever ready to assist you.

    In conclusion I would like to assure honourable Members that I will do my utmost to be worthy of your confidence in me and to uphold the rules, dignity and decorum of this august body.

PRESIDENT'S SPEECH


6.46 p.m.

    The President (Dr Benjamin Henry Sheares): Honourable Members, we meet today under circumstances vastly different from those prevailing when the last Parliament was convened on 6th May, 1968. Then, the prospects were grim. We faced the stark question of survival: how to hold up the economy, to generate jobs, of any kind, to mop up massive unemployment.

Column: 9



    The will to succeed was decisive. Sheer determination, hard work and realistic planning enabled Singapore to make the grade. Imaginative policies, combined with tough measures, have minimised the economic and social dislocation. Today's continuing and controlled boom is giving Singapore that glow of success. There is a bloom which will spread from the city to the new towns, and through to the villages and kampongs in the rural areas.

    Now, the challenge is to maintain and continue this rapid pace of growth for continued high growth rates. Then the trend towards a better life for everyone willing to work will become more pronounced, and in more gracious surroundings.

    We cannot seek fame for sheer size. But we can achieve higher standards in everything, with the emphasis on quality, whether in jobs, schools, hospitals, social and recreational amenities or homes. We can become a centre for excellence in all fields important to our economic and cultural life.

    To achieve this, we must fulfil two pre-conditions. First, smaller families-ideally two children per family - so that more resources and care can be given to each child by the family and the State. Second, Singapore must eschew one of the characteristics of the welfare state syndrome, where everyone expects others, not himself, to work harder to carry the subsidies for services everyone wants. For us, a yet to be developed and fully industrialised society, this selfish rejection of the work ethic is fatal. On the contrary, hard work and high performance must be encouraged and rewarded. No one should get away with enjoying services subsidised through the hard work of others, without making his own contribution, to the best of his ability and capacity.

    After the last war, several countries in the West set out to create a more "cushioned" society. The state promised to provide for everyone, from cradle to grave. In the beginning, they

Column: 10

promised free pre-natal and accouchement services, free medical and dental treatment, free spectacles and dentures, free education, free school meals, heavily subsidised public housing, and generous old-age pensions.

    The idealistic social philosophy was to cushion people from the harshness of personal inadequacies, and the sometimes cruel dispensations of fortune. But, in the course of the last 27 years, this ideal has had to be modified, because of escalating economic costs, and worse, because of the debilitating psychological consequences on the working population. Policy makers soon found out that free services led to excessive use, and much abuse. Gradually, but inevitably even under socialist governments, substantial charges have had to he imposed on these initially almost free services.

    But the greater damage to the spirit and morale of a people was harder to correct. A profound change in attitudes to work, and the absence of personal shouldering of responsibility, have permeated considerable portions of their societies. They have reared a younger generation who now believe that the state owes them a living, a good living. They believe the good things in life are easy to come by, by mass agitation, by strikes, and through confrontation with established authority. Quite a few of the younger trade union leaders do not believe that rewards should be equated to hard work or personal performance. They believe that all should be paid equally, the industrious as well as the indolent. Others, who they are not quite clear about, will generate the wealth, the larger part of which the state can cream off to pay for the comfort and welfare of themselves and their followers.

    In some countries, professionally trained men and women, instead of creating wealth, use their knowledge and ingenuity to defeat the tax collector. Many high income professionals and entrepreneurs stop trying, and even stop working, in order not to make profits just before surtax rates. Or they spend lavishly on expense accounts, and other

Column: 11

frills, to defeat the tax collector. Some even commute to tax-free havens in the Caribbean and elsewhere, for more than six months of a year, to escape income tax on dividends from investments they made in foreign countries. Singapore's policies must not cause this kind of distortion, or the workings of the competitive, achievement-oriented society which have brought us to where we are, will fail.

    We must and can keep our population growth small, so that every child can be better fed, clothed, trained and nurtured. We cannot afford to get into this unhappy vicious circle, the something for nothing syndrome. We must pay for what we want. Everyone must work to earn and pay for what he wants in life.

    In two fundamental areas, there must be heavy subsidies. Good health and good education must be available to all. These are costly objectives. But the user must pay a small percentage of the actual cost. It is to remind him of the enormous cost the rest of society is paying for him. This nominal payment will also prevent abuse in the user of these services.

    My Government intends to allow wages to go up, but in a steady and orderly fashion. However, instead of increasing taxes on his increased earnings, we shall leave the worker with most of the increased income. Thus, the responsibility of what he does with this increased income will rest with each individual. He has to decide whether be wants to spend his money on luxury articles or expensive services he does not really need, or to save his money in buying a home, or putting it in the Post Office Savings Bank or investing it in Government bonds and stocks which yield interest or dividends.

    The principles of our taxation policies must encourage people to want to work hard and to cam more, so that they can save more. High savings lead to high capital accumulation, and, as in Japan, will enable more wealth to be generated.

Column: 12

Taxes will fall at least as much on spending as on earnings, to encourage savings. We should not get caught in the consumer-society before we have become fully developed.

    Everyone will try to earn more if he is allowed to retain the major part of his earnings, to invest in sound enterprises which can further increase his income. Many a newly independent state, barely developed, that have promised to carry their voters from cradle to grave, have had their backs broken. And it will take decades to mend the damage. Even highly developed industrial societies have been beset with ever increasing taxation to meet ever higher subsidies in social services. Even the most affluent have not been able to protect the pensioner and the fixed income groups from being impoverished by inflation. We must learn from the lessons which others have paid bitterly for, that nothing in life is for free.

    On constitutional and security matters, the last few years have shown that some safeguards are necessary. Constitutional amendments will be made early in this session of Parliament, so that no surrender of our sovereignty, or any part thereof, by way of incorporation into, or federation with, any other country is possible, unless two-thirds of the total electorate vote positively for it in a referendum.

    It would be criminal negligence to allow foreign interests with large financial resources to manipulate our internal politics, by financing Singapore political parties, professional, academic and other groups, to try to beguile domestic opinion, especially if their efforts are insidiously multiplied by purveying them through mass media set up and supplied generously with funds for this purpose. No foreign interests can be allowed to take over Singapore through financing and manipulating political parties through their naive or vain, self-proclaimed leaders. Whether fools or knaves, they must be saved from their own follies or villainies when powerful groups set out to use them.

Column: 13



    However, this legislation will not prevent my Government, at present or in the future, from joining other countries inside or outside the region, in arrangements for mutual security, or for economic purposes, such as a free trade area, and perhaps, eventually, even a common market.

    Legislation will also be introduced to ensure that all political parties will have their party expenditure and income periodically inspected. The inspection will be done by Supreme Court Judges, with the help of accountants, auditors and other expert examiners. The purpose of inspection will be to discover whether foreign money has been injected directly or indirectly into any of our political parties. Where the Judge is satisfied that donations are genuinely from Singapore donors, their identities and all other information will not be disclosed, not even to the Government.

    These are present safeguards for future contingencies. For the immediate

Column: 14

present, there are five challenging years ahead. They will not be free from the unexpected. But an alert people, in trim, and prepared to meet sudden dangers, and to respond swiftly to sudden changes, have a more than even chance of overcoming their problems. In the next five years, may the deliberations of honourable Members help us all to achieve, in qualitative terms, what, in the last five, we have achieved in quantitative terms.

    At the conclusion of the President's speech, Mr Speaker, preceded by the Serjeant at Arms, the Clerk, the Clerk-Assistant and the Second Clerk-Assistant, escorted the President (accompanied by two A.D.C.s) out of the Chamber, and the House adjourned without question put, pursuant to the Standing Order.

Eight minutes past Seven o'clock p.m.


Column: 15

ADDENDUM TO PRESIDENTIAL ADDRESS AT THE OPENING OF

THE FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRD PARLIAMENT ON

THURSDAY, 12TH OCTOBER, 1972

MINISTRY OF FINANCE


    For the next few years, the principal objective of financial and economic policy in the Republic is to sustain the momentum of economic growth achieved in the last few years. The package of incentives, the build-up of infrastructure, the sustained effort at industrial promotion in overseas countries and the restructuring of our financial institutions to support economic expansion, they have contributed to the present state of Singapore's economic well-being.

    To sustain the momentum that has been achieved, a policy of "more of the same" would not be entirely adequate. This is because Singapore's targets as well as the socio-economic environment itself are not those of the past. Today, it is no longer a matter of inducing more and more industries into Singapore, whatever the cost. It is possible to be somewhat more discriminating; to seek industries that do not ruin the environment, industries which hold good prospects for the continuous upgrading of manpower skills, be they plant operatives, supervisors and technicians, or higher level engineering and scientific staff, and industries that have a catalytic effect on the economy, encouraging a growth of allied and supporting industries.

    These objectives, however, have to be reached under conditions totally different from those of five years ago. There is no large pool of cheap unemployed workers. But, on the other hand, Singapore's vocational institutes, industrial training centres, Polytechnic and universities are turning out each year more and more of the skilled manpower that industry needs. And work permits are issued, liberally, to those industries and enterprises which upgrade the skills of the workers, or where the level of sophistication of the products manufactured is high.

    A more refined economic policy is required in the new situation to ensure that intending investors, both from overseas

Column: 16

as well as our own citizens, will be able to obtain the essential factors of production - capital, labour and land - in such proportions, grades, skills and quantity as they may require.

    If we succeed in this, we should see a continuation of the fast rate of economic growth of previous years, subject to one proviso. This is that no severe disruption of the international monetary system will occur to seriously affect world trade. An economy like Singapore's, highly geared to export markets of the world, is extremely sensitive to changes in conditions in world trade. There is little that Singapore can do to promote the badly needed reforms of the international monetary system. What it can do is to protect itself against the adverse effects of economic troubles created by such problems. Fortunately for us, sufficient reserves have been accumulated in the past which we can use judiciously to cushion off the worst effects of such crises. Also, the further development of an efficient and highly sophisticated banking and financial sector will help in providing solutions to monetary problems.

    Should conditions be more or less as favourable as in the last five years, our economy will continue its robust rate of growth. The Ministry of Finance should be able to meet its other main obligation, to provide sufficient funds to other ministries for their current as well as development needs. While changes in tax rates and additional taxation may from time to time, be necessary or desirable to effect social or economic policies, continued economic growth will generate the increased funds to be made available to expanding ministries as in the past. As long as the economy is buoyant, and labour-management relations sensible and reasonable, there will be no need to impose major or painful increases in tax rates. But it will be necessary to constantly review the tax machinery to ensure a high level of efficiency, particularly to ferret out tax evasion.

Column: 17



    While rapid economic growth has given tax payers the same tax rates for nearly seven years now, it has created a major problem for the government services. As the demand for skills and talent increases, the problem of attracting and retaining high calibre personnel in the government services has become increasingly severe. It is necessary to reexamine once again the structure of pay and service conditions and to make the rewards in certain departments, ministries, grades and professions more comparable to what they can get in the private sector. This is not a new problem. But whereas in the past we had resorted to ad hoc solutions, it is now necessary to look for a more fundamental and lasting solution.

    Concurrently with increased rewards for, and consequently higher costs of, Government personnel, it will be necessary, by greater mechanisation, and computerisation, to streamline the organisation of the Government and the Statutory Boards to increase efficiency and productivity.

    Finally, to achieve quality in jobs, homes, schools, hospitals, social and recreational amenities, much more money will have to be spent on capital equipment, on more intensive and more prolonged training of skilled workers and technicians. We must increase our capital by adding to it what foreign investors can bring in by way of machinery and foreign exchange in manufacturing industry and finance. More expenditure will go into educating the professionals, engineers, scientists, especially in Applied Sciences, computers and systems analysis, accountants, architects, doctors, managers, bankers, lawyers, economists, and other professionals whose expertise is part and parcel of an industrial society. We are producing more and more middle-technology products, whilst developing into an international banking and financial centre.

Column: 18

MINISTRY OF DEFENCE


    The urgency over our defence build-up has lessened as we now have some defence capability. The emphasis must now be to train men to higher levels of competence, and among the regulars, to develop an increasing sense of professionalism. Further, the range, quality and intensity of training of technical and engineering personnel must be given the highest priority as a modern armed force uses weapons of great complexity and sophistication.

    With proper selection of personnel, with improved systems of training, with a clear-cut policy of career development, we shall achieve quality in commanders and staff officers in whom we entrust so large a proportion of our young men. Then the prodigious effort and enormous sums of money we have put into defence would yield returns in security and stability which an efficient combat force of high discipline, morale and professional skill will provide.

Column: 18

MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS


    We live in vastly a changed world. We are more likely to safeguard what we have all built if we face squarely these changed conditions and make the adjustments, however inconvenient or unpleasant.

    The super powers and the major powers have changed their relationships with each other. They were dramatised by President Nixon's visit to Peking in February, and to Moscow in May. The Japanese Prime Minister's visit to Peking in September in which 23 years of dogma that Taiwan was China was thrown overboard showed how swiftly they have changed their policies to meet a changed situation.

    But as conflict between the super powers themselves is reduced, so their competition for power and influence will sharpen in third countries, in the Middle East, and Southeast Asia. Singapore is neutral and non-aligned insofar as we are asked to take sides between competing power blocs or competing ideologies. But, where our

Column: 19

survival is concerned, we cannot afford to be neutral. We will not stand nonaligned if we are threatened by superior force. However there is no need for the same haste as in 1968, in the build-up of our defence capability.

    In conjunction with our neighbours, through ASEAN, we hope Southeast Asia will remain an area of relative peace and stability, so that now we and our neighbours can concentrate our efforts and resources on the reconstruction of our societies and re-development of our economies. Perhaps eventually a neutral Southeast Asia can be agreed upon and guaranteed by the major powers. But let us not forget that the Swiss were neutral but not unarmed in two world wars. It was because they were capable of considerable defence that it was not necessary for them to demonstrate their capacity. Warring parties respected their neutrality because not to do so would have meant large forces being despatched and tied down, entangled with the Swiss military forces.

Column: 19

MINISTRY OF HOME AFFAIRS


Modernisation of the Police

    With the implementation of the new salaries and conditions of service of junior officers, the Police Force will have officers of better quality and educational standards.

Personnel

    (a) By the end of 1974, all junior officers without a Secondary II education will have been retired. Those who wish to may join in the newly established Commercial and Industrial Security Corporation. The consequential vacancies will be filled by recruitment of junior officers with School Certificate education or its equivalent.

    (b) The reorganisation of the Police Force involves a considerable devolution of responsibilities and duties on to sergeants and constables. These duties had formerly been performed by inspectors and sergeants respectively. A flew training programme designed to

Column: 20

develop and increase the capacity of junior officers to fulfil these functions is already underway. It should be completed over the next three years. Once this devolution of responsibilities has been completed, it will be necessary to review the officer structure and strength of the Police Force.

Criminal investigation

    A centralised Criminal Intelligence Unit has been the subject of detailed study by a committee. Their recommendations have been accepted for implementation.

    An adviser on criminal investigation is being appointed from the United Kingdom Police, with the specific objective of upgrading investigative skills in the Criminal Investigation Department as well as improving the standards of detective training.

    The forensic capability available to the Police Force is developing in close co-ordination with the Chemistry Department.

Prevention of Crime

    Beginning from 1973, a system of team policing will be introduced in two Divisions to replace the traditional beat system. Team policing involves much more use of transport and communications. But it can achieve flexibility in crime prevention patrols. If this system is successful under Singapore conditions, team policing will replace traditional beat system in all Divisions.

Physical Development

    The operational organisation and deployment of the Police requires that police stations and establishments be strategically distributed throughout the island. make for a new layout of control between the policemen on patrol, the patrol car, Police HQ and the plan for new police stations. These changes will be implemented in graduated phases.

Prisons

    Including persons detained under the Criminal Law, the prison population is about 2,400, each of whom costs about $8 a day to maintain. MINISTRY OF EDUCATION

    The second language will be better taught through improved methods, by teachers specially trained to teach the mother tongue as a second language in English schools, and English as a second language in non-English schools. More time is being devoted to this. All teachers will eventually have to be bilingual.

Curriculum Development

    Educational research and curriculum development will lead to a continuous re-evaluation and revision of curricula so that what is taught is relevant to the changing social and economic needs of the nation.

    An Educational Media Service will be established to use the latest in teaching techniques and teaching aids.

    The teaching of subjects will be more related and integrated to avoid compartmentalisation of knowledge.

    More time for extra-curricular activities will be given, by reducing the classroom workload. The stress on extracurricular activities will be encouraged especially in the cadet and other uniformed groups. There will be more refresher courses to enable serving teachers to improve their teaching techniques and capabilities. Staffing

    The Ministry will recruit more suitable graduate teachers, particularly for subjects in which the shortage of teachers is acute. The ratio of graduate to non-graduate teachers will be improved in secondary schools.

Educative Travel

    Students and teachers will be given greater opportunities for educative travel to neighbouring countries through grants from the Education Fund.

School Building Programme

to cater for 8,000 students. The Ngee Ann Technical College will develop and expand its facilities eventually to take in 3,000.

    The Adult Education Board's programme of recreational and enrichment courses will be expanded. They are to encourage the public to spend their leisure in more wholesome pursuits giving them more satisfaction through accomplishing something useful.

Private Schools

    In order to safeguard public interest regulations will be introduced for better control of private schools, correspondence schools and kindergartens.

    Since the reorganisation of the Public Bus Service 18 months ago, the three public bus companies have added over

MINISTRY OF LABOUR


    Singapore's primary asset is not natural but human resources. It is the intelligence, skills, discipline, efficiency and willingness to learn and to work of our workers, managers and entrepreneurs which decide our pace of economic progress.

I. HUMAN RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT



Labour supply

    We will allow industries or enterprises with higher skill or higher technology

Column: 29

content, and those with prospects of going on to more sophisticated manufacture, to recruit labour on work permits liberally. However, female migrant workers employed in industry should have some primary education. Moreover, all work permit holders, male or female, will have a temporary work permit until they have passed a medical examination. This is to help ensure that the strength of our labour force is not weakened with the infusion of work permit holders of poor education or health.

    To increase the pool of our indigenous labour force, more Singapore women will be encouraged to seek employment. More women will work if wages were higher, and there are provision of creches and kindergartens, and if clean factories are sited near or in Housing and Development Board estates. Part-time employment, and contracting of work to housewives in their homes on piece-rate (particularly in the manufacture of garments and textiles) will tap a vast reservoir of labour at present not utilised. Higher female employment will increase the total family incomes and improve social conditions of the lower paid families.

Skill acquisition

    Our workers must acquire skills appropriate to a modern, industrial society. Our industries must not be hampered by skill shortages.

    The Government proposes to establish an Industrial Training Board. The Board will undertake and co-ordinate all aspects of industrial training, including apprenticeship schemes, on-the-job and off-the-job training. Employers have promised to support these schemes as they will make available the skilled manpower they need.

    As our industrial and commercial enterprises become more sophisticated, the need for high-quality managerial expertise becomes vital. This is true of both large and small establishments. The National Productivity Board aims to raise the quality of management, particularly in its relationship with, and efficient use of, workers.

Column: 30



Labour utilisation

    The task of the recently reorganised Employment Service of the Ministry is not simply to find jobs for the unemployed. By matching unemployed workers and job vacancies faster, by raising job satisfaction through better matching of worker aptitude and ability with job requirements, and by providing more accurate labour market information, the Employment Service will improve labour utilisation.

II. INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS



    The guiding principle of "Industrial Peace with Justice" is as valid today as it was 13 years ago. There will undoubtedly be disagreement over distribution of the fruits of economic growth. It will be the task of the National Wages Council periodically to establish equitable wage guidelines acceptable to both management and labour without adversely affecting our economic growth, whilst ensuring a rising living standard for workers. Workers must get an equitable share of higher productivity and profits, if they are to give of their best and identify themselves with the enterprise they work for.

    We shall regulate increases in wages and salaries in a steady and equitable manner, not too low a rate to cause disappointment, not too high to cause inflation, with more money chasing the same amount of homes and services, causing more imports of unnecessary luxury goods, leading to a drain of foreign exchange. The danger most to be avoided is wage increases of a magnitude that pushes the cost of our services and manufactured products up until they become uncompetitive in the international markets.

    The National Wages Council, unions, employers and the Government must work together. They must not simply seek their own sectional interests of higher profits and higher wages, and in so doing defeat our national purpose of more exports and more investments to generate more wealth. Wages and profits must be such that returns on equity remain high, attracting more invest-

Column: 31

ments, whilst workers get a fair share of an ever- increasing cake which their harder work and increased productivity have made possible.

    Hitherto, industrial relations functions of the Ministry have been mainly "curative" in nature. Preventive measures will now receive greater attention. The object is to prevent or eliminate nascent points of friction between labour and management before they assume ominous proportions.

    The guiding ethos of industrial relations should be co-operation not corn-bat, reflection not agitation. The Labour Ministry will do its part to bring about this mature industrial relations through education, persuasion, and promotion of institutional arrangements through improved communications and reduce tensions between labour and management.

III. WORKERS' WELFARE



    Workers are human beings and not mere cogs in the wheels of production. Their health and welfare are of prime importance. A worker is more efficient and productive if he has a clean environment, better educational, recreational and cultural facilities, and good amenities at his place of work. The Ministry will protect the growing industrial work force from occupational hazards and diseases. The Factory Inspectorate and Industrial Health Unit will be expanded in scope and size, and staffed with qualified professional and technical personnel so as to prevent and reduce industrial accidents and diseases.

    An expanded Labour Inspectorate will more stringently ensure that minimum standards embodied in existing labour laws are respected and enforced. More inspections will be carried out by the Labour Inspectorate to check on observance of protective legislation and to assist employers to understand and comply with the law. Where any employer persists in infringing labour laws, causing harm to their workers, the Ministry will prosecute them.

    Employers' contributions to the Central Provident Fund have been increased with effect from 1st July, 1972, from

Column: 32

10 per cent to 12 per cent for employees earning less than $200 monthly and from 10 per cent to 14 per cent for those earning more than $200 monthly. The higher rates mean better provision for workers in their old age. Moreover, the higher rates will raise the home-owning capacity of workers. Up to this month, 26,466 Central Provident Fund members had withdrawn 590,080,022 to purchase Housing and Development Board and Jurong Town Corporation flats.

    The establishment of joint consultative machinery in all enterprises will be encouraged so that workers and employers can understand and appreciate one another's problems.

    Finally, with higher incomes, the worker will be encouraged to constantly improve his knowledge and skills, in adult and workers education courses and refresher courses so that he can further increase his capacity in more productive labour.

MINISTRY OF NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT


Public Housing

    Since 1960 two 5-year building programmes for public housing have been completed and two satellite towns --Queenstown and Toa Payoh--created. Altogether 137,000 units of flats had been completed by the end of 1971 and about 750,000 people (37 per cent of the population) are now living in Housing and Development Board flats. The third 5-year building programme (1971-75) has commenced and two new towns will be built at Telok Blangah and Woodlands. The third 5-year building programme will provide an additional 100,000 units of flats to house 500,000 more people.

    The policy of allowing the use of Central Provident Fund for the purchase of flats has made it possible for many citizens to buy their own homes. More than 40,000 families now own the flats they occupy. However, this policy has also resulted in greater demand for HDB flats. There are now 70,000 applicants on the waiting list (47,000 to buy and

Column: 33

23,000 to rent). The Housing and Development Board will therefore speed up its present building rate of one flat every 26 minutes.

    Because of higher incomes and higher CPF savings, we must build almost twice as many units as we have built in the last five years. However, with each unit averaging about twice the floorspace per unit, this means quadrupling the building capacity of the HDB flats. This must be done without lowering the quality of layout and planning. The standard of finish of the new high-rise flats from the outside, in the design and appearance, and inside for the occupants, must be good. We must avoid another sudden surge in demand for building material and construction workers, which a few years ago pushed building costs up.

    When the Housing and Development Board first began building in 1960, the object was to provide homes as quickly as possible with little attention being paid to the residents' needs for recreation. Now that the back of the housing problem has been broken, the Board can and will provide more facilities for rest and recreation. In existing HDB estates more parks and swimming pools will be provided where there is land available. In Toa Payoh a sports complex including four swimming pools is under construction. Additional swimming pools will be built in Queenstown. New swimming pool complexes will be built at Henderson Road/Jalan Bukit Merah, Bukit Ho Swee, Tanjong Rhu/ Kallang Airport Estates, MacPherson Estates and Kallang Basin Estates. The new housing estates (for example, Telok Blangah, Woodlands, Bedok and Ang Mo Kio) will be better planned and have not only better designed and more comfortable homes, but also larger open spaces and more parks, swimming pools and sports complexes. In every neighbourhood, well-equipped children's playgrounds will be provided in addition to sports facilities, such as basket-ball and badminton courts. Land will also be set aside for the construction of community centres. The ground floors of each block of flats will be free for indoor sports, like table tennis, and children to play

in. The Board will spend about $75 million during the next five years to provide recreational facilities.

Urban Renewal

    Slum clearance and redevelopment of the central area will be accelerated so that better housing and living environment will replace the congested and dilapidated housing conditions in the inner city. People living in areas under clearance will be temporarily inconvenienced by resettlement and a change of their habits in the old environment they have got accustomed to. Comprehensive planning of urban renewal will be carried out to reduce inconvenience and hardship to a minimum. An Urban Renewal Authority will be established by 1st April, 1973, to implement a systematic programme of redevelopment of the Central area including housing, commercial and shopping centres, entertainment and recreational facilities, car parking, road traffic and pedestrian circulation, parks and landscaped walkways. A new and gracious city will be created. At the same time, buildings and monuments of historical and architectural value are being preserved and placed in a more attractive setting.

Condominium Housing

    Many private housing estates of mainly terrace and semi-detached houses have been built in the past. This type of development is wasteful in land use and produces heavily built up and congested areas entirely covered with roofs and tarmac with little open space. This will bring the prices of housing within the reach of many more of our citizens and complement the efforts of the Housing and Development Board in providing more homes for the people.

Public Works

    The public works projects in the construction and improvement of roads, bridges, schools, hospitals, parks and playgrounds will continue to be implemented. The Pan-Island Expressway

running in east-west direction will eventually form an essential highway linking several satellite towns. Medicine and Public Health, the Department of Parasitology, the Vector Control Unit, the evaluation unit of the Family Planning and Population Board. It is being established in conjunction with SEAMEO. It is primarily a research and graduate teaching institute.

Family Planning and Population Control

    But all these are palliative measures. The basic solution is a lower birth rate. Then we can raise our standard of life and quality of the environment. Accouchement fees, maternity leave, priority points for homes will be so adjusted that they will bring about the ideal of the two children per family. For the Singapore of the 1970's the third child is a luxury. The fourth and fifth are anti-social acts. These charges will take full effect after 9 1/2 months from today, i.e., 1st August, 1973. Housing Board priorities will also be changed. The highest priorities are for those who have two or less children, whether for their first flat, or for transfer to a better flat. Families with three will drop slightly in priority. Families with four or more will have little priority. This will be implemented so as not to be harsh to those who already have large families. But after 9 1/2 months from today, 1st August, 1973, any addition to two children means declining priority in balloting for purchase or rentals of flats. Any increase in family size beyond two will mean lower priority in transfers to bigger flats, either for purchase or rentals.

    The second 5-year National Family Planning Programme (1971-1975) is directed at two main target groups: -

    (1) The between 15 per cent to 18 per cent of married women known as the "hard core" belonging to the low income and high parity groups who have not taken to family planning.

    (2) The newly weds whose numbers have increased significantly. Even if the relatively low fertility level of 1970 remains constant the crude birth rate will actually increase to 24,5 per thousand in 1975 and 25.7 per thousand in 1980. (See Appendix II, cols. 53-4.) This is because the number of women of reproductive age will have increased by about 170,000 a 25 per cent increase. (See Appendix III, cols. 55-6.) The aim is to further dampen fertility,

so that the crude birth rate will fall to about 18.4 per thousand in 1975 and 14.8 per thousand in 1980. Then the rate of natural increase will be less than 1 per cent by 1980.

    More use of sterilization as a means of family planning for those who have completed their families will be advocated.

    The present scheme to give priority to comprehensive dental coverage to all primary schools will continue. This service is being extended to kindergarten children. They will continue to do so.

MINISTRY OF THE ENVIRONMENT


    The Ministry of the Environment will tackle the problems of pollution, to protect and enhance our environment, to increase our water resources, and to maintain high standards of public health. We need never face the high degree of danger to public health that is threatening some of the polluted cities of the industrial countries. But we must deal, now, firmly and rationally with pollution. National development and pollution control must go hand in hand.

    To keep up the quality of the environment in the face of industrialisation and urbanisation means considerable planning and expenditure on anti-pollution. As incomes go up, so does consumption. There will be more high-rise flats, more cars, buses and taxis, more refuse and garbage from each household, glass bottles, plastic containers and other waste. More electricity will be generated for more factories and homes, i.e, more sulphur dioxide belching from power stations and soot and chemical dust from factory chimneys. There is increasing pollution from the expanding oil refineries, both in the southern islands and on Singapore itself.

    We must take steps now to prevent a deterioration into a Tokyo-type situation. The air we breathe must be clean. The noise of traffic, radios, television, and rumbling machines, must be cut down. Most important of all, the pollution of our water through domestic or industrial waste running into open drains must be stopped, as soon as is technically and economically possible. Rain water must be collected unpolluted for domestic consumption. Several big, new impounding reservoirs are in the course of construction. The costs are high. But they cannot be avoided. We cannot have our reservoirs filled up with polluted water. Every factory has been, and is being, given enough time to install measures to cut down the deleterious substances that they discharge either into open drains or into sewers. The sewerage network will be expanded rapidly

Column: 42

to all built-up areas. Hard detergents will go, to be replaced by soft ones. All domestic waste water from kitchens, from the washing of clothes, and from bathrooms must go into sewers, and not into open drains. Over 6,000 pig sties and chicken-runs in the catchment areas of Pandan, Kranji, Bedok and Seletar reservoirs will have to be reconstructed so that waste from pigs and other animals will go into sewers and do not pollute the rain water that falls in the catchment.

    We must do this for all of us, not for any sectional or privileged groups. Most people are aware of these grave continuing problems. We cannot allow these problems to become more complicated, by dithering or balking at temporarily unpopular measures. The consequences of not inconveniencing the polluter, now, is to face a grave or even critical position in five to seven years' time.

Water resources

    The management and development of our water resources will be better coordinated under a single Ministry. Coordinated sewerage and drainage projects with the covering enforcement of anti-pollution legislation are primary preventive measures to conserve water.

Sewerage

    A comprehensive Master Plan for the collection and treatment of sewage in Singapore will be completed. This will be followed by the drawing up of detailed development programmes. The pace of sewerage projects will be' stepped up. Priorities on sewerage projects given to Housing and Development Board, Jurong Town Corporation and other large Government developments will now be extended to Upper Bukit Timah-Woodlands areas. The importance of well-planned and executed sewerage projects cannot be over-emphasised. It is one of the major long term solutions to our water pollution and conservation problem. The control of all trade and industrial waste will now come under a single department.

Column: 43



Drainage

    The role of drainage will now no longer be confined to the task of flood alleviation but will serve multi-purposes, aimed at creating both a better environment as well as the abstraction of drainage waters for selective uses.

Water Pollution Act

    Present legislation on water pollution control will be revised to give sufficient teeth to ensure that those for whom facilities and expertise are available, to control pollution, will act to prevent pollution. A comprehensive Water Pollution Bill will be presented to Parliament.

Solid Waste Disposal

    The disposal of solid wastes would become a pressing problem as available dumping grounds become scarce. Modern techniques of compaction and incineration will be introduced in the near future to conserve land and water.

Mechanisation of Street Cleansing

    The recent introduction of mechanisation of street cleansing is to meet the problem of the present shortage of cleansing workers. More machines will be acquired. In the process of mechanisation, the upgrading of the skill of our workers is necessary for these machines to be maintained and used efficiently.

Hawkers

    The magnitude and complexity of the hawker problem is seen in the numbers, diversity and dispersion of hawkers in the city centre, in the rural districts, in public and private housing and industrial estates. The socio-economic grounds for their existence in Singapore is recognised. The present programme of building markets and hawker centres to resite licensed street hawkers into hygienic and pollution-free surroundings will be extended.

    Both public authorities and private developers have to consider the building of suitable indoor accommodation to serve hawker-type food. It is an essential social amenity to domestic residents, factory and office workers, and, `others. Such a programme will quickly

Column: 44

improve the existing street hawker conditions and forestall graver problems for the future.

    After spending large sums of public and private funds we should not be frustrated by an uncontrolled proliferation of illegal hawkers, or by a lowering of personal and food hygiene standards. The Ministry will educate hawkers and enforce public health standards. At the same time firm action will be taken against unlicensed hawkers.

Air Pollution

    We should now be more careful in the types of industries that are allowed. Heavy pollution industries will not be allowed. Existing industries which are causing too much pollution will have to install anti-pollution devices, or they will have to move elsewhere.

    In the city area, there will be more intensive surveillance to control emissions from motor vehicles. Noisy and old motor vehicles, whether private or commercial vehicles or buses or taxis must be gradually eliminated. This will reduce the noise level in the city areas. New regulations will be made to control carbon monoxide and other residual pollutants from exhausts to improve the air. Most cities of the developed world are already doing this.

    Later, as a further step, certain industries and trade premises in the city areas will have to use low sulphur fuel oil or gas. This will reduce the emission of smoke and sulphur dioxide.

    Open burning of domestic and industrial refuse also adds to the pollution of the air. This practice will have to be controlled and regulated. Either the wastes go into incinerators, or they are used for the manufacture of by-products, e.g. sawdust to hard board.

Cemeteries

    To conserve land, particularly in the urban areas, cemeteries in and around the city will be closed. There will be extensions to existing public cemeteries in the Chua Chu Kang area and development of new cemeteries in other areas. But cremation is the long term solution. A new crematoria and columbarium will be developed.

Column: 45

PUBLIC UTILITIES BOARD


    The increasing tempo of industrialisation and the massive building construction in both the public and private sectors have brought about unprecedented demands for the services provided by the PUB.

Electricity

    Consumption of electricity for the first eight months of this year has increased by 22 per cent.

    Stage II of the Jurong Power Station (costs: $133 million) is scheduled for completion by the last quarter of 1973. A new power station (costs: $191.4 million) is being built at Senoko. Stage I will have a capacity of 360 megawatts. The first turbo-alternator set of 120 megawatts is scheduled for commissioning in mid-1975. A gas turbo-alternator station (costs: $10.6 million) with two generators is being constructed at Senoko. Its first generator set will be ready for commissioning at the end of this year. In 1973 the Board will introduce a new 230 kv network system to ensure adequate and reliable transmission capacity to handle the anticipated future large bulk load transfers.

    The Board is extending its rural electrification programme. Since the inception of the rural electrification programme in March 1963, over 400 schemes benefitting some 230,000 people have been implemented. The Board plans to implement another 70 schemes before the end of 1974, to make electricity available to even the remotest areas in Singapore.

Water

    Consumption of water for the first eight months of this year has increased by 5.9 per cent. The Board has under planning and execution projects to meet this increasing demand. After the North East Monsoon is over by January there will be new block tariffs for water.

    To enhance our water resources in Singapore we have to pay higher costs in anti-pollution and special treatment

Column: 46

measures. We are also using up valuable land for new reservoirs: -

    (i) The Upper Peirce Scheme (costs: $71.2 million) is scheduled for completion by 1974. It involves the construction of another impounding reservoir and will increase by eight times the capacity of the existing Peirce Reservoirs;

    (ii) The Kranji/Pandan Scheme (costs: $74.2 million), now under construction, will be completed by 1975. It will increase the maximum storage capacity of our impounding reservoirs by about 42 per cent;

    (iii) The Jalan Eunos Service Reservoir is being further extended (costs: $1.3 million) from 15 million gallons by another 7.4 million gallons;

    (iv) Construction of another service reservoir at Mt. Faber II (costs: $3.7 million) is in progress and is scheduled for completion in 1973.

    The average per capita consumption continues to increase. A significant portion of it is wasted. The Board is working out new water tariffs for domestic consumption. They will provide for water at a low basic rate to meet the ordinary domestic needs of a family. Beyond this basic quota the rates will progressively increase. The purpose of these progressively higher tariffs for unnecessary high domestic consumption of water is not to increase revenue but to prevent the waste of water. On the contrary we must encourage frugal usage of water. Some domestic water can be used twice over, for example, re-using water used for bathing and washing of clothes, for the flushing of toilets.

    To ensure equitable rationing during periods of drought and to avoid disorderly scrambling at public standpipes, the Board will phase out all public standpipes. It will extend its water distribution system. About 60 miles of water mains were laid in 197 1-72 to

Column: 47

supply water to housing and industrial estates as well as rural areas where standpipes had been removed and sites demarcated for redevelopment.

    Consumption of gas for the first eight months of this year has increased by about 5.6 per cent.

    Construction work on the eighth gas-making plant (costs: $1.5 million), a 3.5 million cubic feet (85,000 cubic meters) per day Zimmer Reformer, has commenced and is expected to be commissioned by the middle of 1973. A new 1,000-ton naphtha storage tank is now being constructed and will be completed early next year to increase the storage of naphtha at Kallang Gasworks from 600 to 1,600 tons. There are at present more that 520 miles of gas mains in Singapore supplying gas to over 100,000 homes.

Column: 47

MINISTRY OF CULTURE


    The Ministry of Culture helps to mould the social and cultural development of the people, particularly the young.

    The various facilities provided by Radio and Television Singapore, the National Library, the National Theatre and the People's Association are aimed at fulfilling the cultural, social and recreational needs of a sophisticated society. A balance between the educational and the entertaining form of books, magazines, TV and Radio can give more meaning to the use of leisure,

    Singaporeans are by nature hardworking and achievement-oriented. The pursuit of material well-being comes naturally. But it is also necessary for a people to appreciate things of aesthetic value, to be intellectually alive, appreciative and responsive to the beautiful. The "Music for Everyone" and "Art for Everyone" series of concerts and art exhibitions will be continued. The stress will continue to be put on mass participation in the fields of aesthetjc creation and appreciation.

    Radio and Television Singapore will continue to provide services to inform,

Column: 48

entertain and educate. It will increase the range of its programmes aimed at actively involving our youths in wholesome and creative activities. We must stimulate the younger generation to be conscious of the world around us, and our own hardwon advances they must protect. The mass media both Government and private must help to inculcate the virtues of patriotism, pride in national effort and achievement, and the importance of team-work and national endeavour so necessary for group success.

    The National Library has greatly expanded its range of facilities. It has a role to play in encouraging the habit of wide reading, and cultivating an enquiring mind among our young through making available a wide range of journals and publications.

    The People's Association will concentrate on social and recreational programmes. More holiday accommodation will be provided for the people. It will also aim at variety in its activities for youths. Several new community centres will have to be built to cater for an increasing number of those who are interested in making the most of their leisure time, especially those in the new satellite towns. Only by better and new premises and amenities can the People's Association continue to contribute to social cohesion by bringing together all sectors of society to participate in common activities.

    The Museum, which has now come under this Ministry, is being re-organised as a display centre devoted to the art, history and anthropology of the peoples of this region. The art collection of the University of Singapore will soon be made more accessible to' the public by its transfer to the National Museum at Stamford Road.

Column: 48

MINISTRY OF SOCIAL AFFAIRS


    In any society, social deviants can always be found. The Government will have continually to take preventive' measures to keep the incidence of crime and juvenile delinquency at a low level. The Government will help offenders readjust to society to become

Column: 49

law-abiding and socially useful citizens. With industrialisation and urbanisation, the pressure of life is increasing. The traditional stabilising forces of social control in our Asian culture are upset in parts. There is a tendency for new patterns of crime and delinquency of a more sophisticated nature to emerge. Their control will depend upon how the Government and all of us in the community can take preventive action to keep the family unit from loosening. Parental care and control over their teenage children must not deteriorate.

    The Government has already planned for the general strengthening of the existing system of social welfare for the proper care of the destitute, the handicapped and others not in a position to take care of themselves or to be taken care of by relatives and friends. The Ministry will encourage greater community participation in the welfare programmes.

    In order to mobilise more women for full-time employment to relieve the shortage of labour in Singapore, the Government intends to build more creches, especially in housing estates where there is demand for such facilities. Creche hours will also be extended for the convenience of the working mothers.

    The Ministry will encourage the use of all manpower resources available, including handicapped persons. The latter, if given proper training and guidance and equipped with the necessary skills, could be a not insignificant

Column: 50

source of manpower to meet the increasing requirements of our industries.

    The Ministry has laid the foundation for a radical change in our sporting world. New concepts, new facilities, better organisation, a co-ordinated policy - all go towards the making of a new era for sports. Fundamental to this change is the need to meet the changing demands of our youthful population. With greater industrialisation there must be greater emphasis on community programmes which can catch the imagination of our young people.

    A great task lies ahead for all those connected with the promotion of sports in Singapore. If the enthusiasm, dynamism and the co-operative spirit so far shown by the various leaders of the sports organisations is sustained, we can consolidate the framework to provide the programmes for mass participation in all kinds of sport activities.

    Ours must be a robust and a rugged society. Our young people need to grow up healthy, free from the evil influences of drug addiction and hippism. They must not be lured by the fads and fetishes of alien sub-cultures. Our youth must be encouraged to participate in community programmes, using their leisure in a positive and wholesome way. More facilities for sports and recreation will be provided to enable this to be more the way of life in Singapore.
